A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.

A subset S of a ring R is called a subring if S is a subgroup with respect to the addition on R and a submonoid with respect to the multiplication on R. S inherits the laws of composition from R and is itself a ring.

Let $R$ and $R'$ be rings. A map $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a ring homomorphism if it satisfies two conditions: (i) $\varphi(a+b)=\varphi(a)+\varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$, making $\varphi$ a group homomorphism with respect to addition, and (ii) $\varphi(a \cdot b)=\varphi(a) \cdot \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$ and $\varphi(1)=1$, making $\varphi$ a monoid homomorphism with respect to multiplication.

A proper ideal $\mathfrak{m} \subsetneq R$ in a ring $R$ is called a maximal ideal if for any ideal $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ that contains $\mathfrak{m}$, $\mathfrak{a}$ must be either $\mathfrak{m}$ or $R$.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
The extension field $L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if every element $\alpha \in L$ is algebraic over $K$.

An extension field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. This field is uniquely characterized up to isomorphism as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$.

A ring \(R\) is called Noetherian if every ascending chain of ideals \(\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subset \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subset \ldots \subset R\) becomes stationary after finitely many steps, or equivalently, every ideal of \(R\) is finitely generated.

The Klein four-group, denoted as $\mathfrak{V}_{4}$, is a subgroup of $\mathfrak{S}_{4}$ consisting of the permutations $\{\mathrm{id}, (1,2)(3,4), (1,3)(2,4), (1,4)(2,3)\}$. It is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} / 2 \mathbb{Z}$.
A tensor is a multi-dimensional array, generalizing the concept of a scalar, vector and matrix.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: An algebraic field extension (ID: 7) is a specialization of an extension field (ID: 8) because every algebraic field extension is by definition an extension field where every element is algebraic over the base field.
